posts.title: 4 Useful Command line Tools to Monitor MySQL Performance in Linux
posts.text: source: https://www.tecmint.com/mysql-performance-monitoring/ 4 command line tools to monitor MySQL database uptime, load and performance in Linux. Uptime: means how long the database has been running and up since its last shutdown or restart. it helps system administrators to check the status of MySQL database about how many queries per second that MySQL database serves, threads, slow queries and lots of interesting statistics Mytop is open source and free console-based (non-gui) monitoring tool displays statistics about threads, queries, slow queries, uptime, load, etc. (in tabular format) much similar to top indirectly helps the administrators to optimize and improve performance of MySQl to handle large requests and decrease server load. How to Install Mytop (MySQL Monitoring) in Linux mtop (MySQL top) is a another similar open source, command line based real time MYSQL Server monitoring tool display results in tabular format much like mytop monitors MySQL queries which are taking the most amount of time to finish and kills those long running queries after certain specified time enable us to identify performance related problems, configuration information, performance statistics and tuning related tips from the command line interface but mtop is not actively maintained and may not work on newly installed MySQL versions How to Install Mtop (MySQL Monitoring) in Linux Innotop is a real time advanced command line based investigation program monitor local and remote MySQL servers running under InnoDB engine includes many features and comes with different types of modes/options helps us to monitor various aspects of MySQL performance to find out what’s wrong going with MySQL server. How to Install Innotop (MySQL Monitoring) in Linux mysqladminis a default command line MySQL client that comes pre-installed with MySQL package for performing administrative operations such as: monitoring processes checking server configuration reloading privileges current status setting root password changing root password create/drop databases and much more. 1mysqladmin -u root -p version # check the mysql status as well as uptime you must have root permission ConclusionIf you’re looking for a good monitor tool for your own work, I recommend mytop and innotop. I used to depend on mytop for my daily monitoring purposes, but now I shifted to innotop, because it displays much more statistics and information, including important transactions.

posts.title: How To Backup Databases Using mysqldump Tool
posts.text: source: http://www.mysqltutorial.org/how-to-backup-database-using-mysqldump.aspx MySQL GUI tools, often provide features for backup MySQL dbs with ease phpMyAdmin SQLyog Problem:the backup process could be very slow if your db is bigbecause: the backup file needs to be transferred across the network to your client PC Features of mysqldump: best solution if your db is big a very useful tool for backing up or dumping MySQL dbs locally on the server very fast located in the root/bin folder of MySQL installation folder. can be used to dump dbs for backup or transfer db to another db server The dump file contains a set of SQL statements to create db objects. can be used to generate CSV, delimited or XML files How to backup a MySQL db (Export) the bd first has to exist structure + data1mysqldump -u username –ppassword db_name > c:\temp\backup001.sql all db structure and data will be exported into a single [backup001.sql] dump file structure only (-d, –no-data option)12345mysqldump -u username –ppassword -no-data db_name > c:\temp\backup002.sql# backup002.sql is a dump filemysqldump -d -u username -ppassword --all-databases > filename.sql# (-d option) + for all dbs data Only (–no-create-info option)There is a case that you want to refresh data in staging and development system so the data in those systems are the same as the production system. In this case, you just need to export data only from the production system and import it to staging and development system 1mysqldump –u username –ppassword –no-create-info db_name > c:\temp\backup002.sql backup multiple MySQL databases into a single file12345# separate databases by ','mysqldump -u username –ppassword dbname1,dbname2 > dump_file.sql# –all-database (option): If you want to backup all databasesmysqldump -u username –ppassword –all-database > dump_file.sql ExtraWith Compression1mysqldump -u username -ppassword --all-databases | gzip -9 > [filename.sql.gz] IF NOT EXIST or DROP DATABASE12345678# Without CREATE DATABASE….IF NOT EXIST or DROP DATABASE …mysqldump -u username -ppassword db_name > filename.sql# with CREATE … IF NOT EXISTmysqldump -u username -ppassword --databases db_name > filename.sql# with CREATE … IF NOT EXIST and DROP DATABASEmysqldump -u username -ppassword --databases --add-drop-database db_name > filename.sql Importing12345678# Extract Gzipped MySQL Export Filegunzip [filename.sql.gz]# Import Multiple MySQL Databases from SQL Filemysql -u username -ppassword < filename.sql# Import Single MySQL Databases from SQL Filemysql -u username -p -D [db_name] -o < filename.sql # Note: Create the database first

posts.title: MySQL Cheat Sheet
posts.text: source: http://www.mysqltutorial.org/mysql-cheat-sheet.aspx the most commonly used MySQL commands and statements that help you work with MySQL more effectively. MySQL CommandsAccess MySQL server from the mysql client using a username and password (MySQL will prompt for a password)1mysql -u [username] -p; Access a specific db using a username and password:1mysql -u [username] -p [db]; Exit1exit; Export data using mysqldump tool1mysqldump -u [username] -p [db] > data_backup.sql; To clear MySQL screen console window on Linux, you use the following command:1mysql> system clear; Currently, there is no command available on Windows for clearing MySQL screen console window. Working with Database12345678CREATE DATABASE [IF NOT EXISTS] db_name; -- Create a db if it does not existUSE db_name; -- Use db or change current db to another db you are working withDROP DATABASE [IF EXISTS] db_name; -- Drop a db permanently.-- /!\ All physical file associated with the db is no longer exists.show databases; -- Show all available dbs Working with Table1234567891011121314151617-- Lists all tables in a current db.show tables;-- Create a new table or a temporary tableCREATE [TEMPORARY] TABLE [IF NOT EXISTS] table( key type(size) NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, c1 type(size) NOT NULL, c2 type(size) NULL, ...);CREATE [TEMPORARY] TABLE [IF NOT EXISTS] table( key type(size) NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, c1 type(size) NOT NULL, c2 type(size) NULL, ...); Altering table structure (There are many actions that you can use)123456789101112131415161718192021-- Add a new columnALTER TABLE table ADD [COLUMN];-- Drop an existing columnALTER TABLE table DROP [COLUMN];-- Add an index to a table on a column.ALTER TABLE table ADD INDEX [name](column, ...);-- Add primary keyALTER TABLE table ADD PRIMARY KEY (column,...)-- Remove primary keyALTER TABLE table DROP PRIMARY KEY-- Deleting table structure and data permanently.DROP TABLE [IF EXISTS] table [, name2, ...][RESTRICT | CASCADE]-- Get information about a table or a column.DESCRIBE table [column] Working with Index123456-- Creating an index on a tableCREATE [UNIQUE|FULLTEXT] INDEX index_nameON table (column,...)-- Removing a specified index from tableDROP INDEX index_name Querying DataSimple Queries123456789101112131415SELECT * FROM tableSELECT column, column2….FROM table;SELECT DISTINCT (column)FROM table;SELECT *FROM tableWHERE condition;-- using aliasSELECT column_1 AS new_column_1, ...FROM table from multiple tables12345678-- using inner join or left joinSELECT * FROM table_1INNER JOIN table_2 ON conditionsSELECT * FROM table1LEFT JOIN table2 ON conditions Counting rows12SELECT COUNT (*)FROM table Sorting123SELECT column, column2, ...FROM tableORDER BY column ASC [DESC], column2 ASC [DESC],...; GROUP BY clause123SELECT *FROM tableGROUP BY column_1, column_2, ...; Filter group of rows using both GROUP BY and HAVING clauses.1234SELECT *FROM tableGROUP BY column_1HAVING condition; Modifying Datainsert1234567INSERT INTO table(column1,column2,...)VALUES(value_1,value_2,...);INSERT INTO table(column1,column2,...)VALUES(value_1,value_2,...), (value_1,value_2,...), (value_1,value_2,...)... update12345678UPDATE tableSET column_1 = value_1, ...UPDATE tableSET column_1 = value_1, ...WHERE condition Update with join1234UPDATE table_1, table_2INNER JOIN table_1 ON table_1.column_1 = table_2.column_1SET column_1 = value_1,WHERE condition Delete 1234567891011-- Delete all rowsDELETE FROM table;DELETE FROM tableWHERE condition;-- Delete with joinDELETE table_1, table2FROM table_1INNER JOIN table_2 ON table_1.column_1 = table_2.column_2WHERE condition; Search1234567-- using LIKE operatorSELECT * FROM tableWHERE column LIKE '%value%'-- using a RegEx with RLIKE operatorSELECT * FROM tableWHERE column RLIKE 'regular_expression'

posts.title: 20 MySQL (Mysqladmin) Commands for Database Administration in Linux
posts.text: source: https://www.tecmint.com/mysqladmin-commands-for-database-administration-in-linux/ some very useful “mysqladmin” commands that are used by system/database administrators in their day-to-day work mysqladminIt is a command-line utility the comes with MySQL serverused by DBA to perform some basic MySQL tasks easily such as: setting root password changing root password monitoring mysql processes reloading privileges checking server status etc. set MySQL Root passwordIf you have fresh installation of MySQL server,then it doesn’t required any password to connect it as root user. 1mysqladmin -u root password YOURNEWPASSWORD Change MySQL Root password12mysqladmin -u root -p123456 password 'xyz123'# old password: 123456, new password: xyz123 check MySQL Server is runningTo find out whether MySQL server is up and running12mysqladmin -u root -p ping# --> mysqld is alive Check which MySQL version I am running12mysqladmin -u root -p version# shows MySQL version along with the current running status Find out current Status of MySQL server12mysqladmin -u root -ptmppassword status# shows the status of uptime with running threads and queries check status of all MySQL Server Variable’s and value’s12mysqladmin -u root -p extended-status# check all the running status of MySQL server variables and values see all MySQL server Variables and Values12mysqladmin -u root -p variables# To see all the running variables and values of MySQL server check all the running Process of MySQL server12mysqladmin -u root -p processlist# display all the running process of MySQL database queries create a Database in MySQL server12345mysqladmin -u root -p create databasename# To create a new databasemysql -u root -p # connectmysql> show databases; # Verify drop a Database1234mysqladmin -u root -p drop databasename...# You will be asked to confirm press ‘y‘Do you really want to drop the 'databasename' database [y/N] y reload/refresh MySQL Privileges12345mysqladmin -u root -p reload;# tells the server to reload the grant tablesmysqladmin -u root -p refresh# flushes all tables and reopens the log files. shutdown MySQL server Safely12345mysqladmin -u root -p shutdown# to start/stop MySQL server/etc/init.d/mysqld stop/etc/init.d/mysqld start Some useful MySQL Flush commands1234567891011121314151617mysqladmin -u root -p flush-hosts# Flush all host information from host cachemysqladmin -u root -p flush-tables# Flush all tablesmysqladmin -u root -p flush-threads# Flush all threads cachemysqladmin -u root -p flush-logs# Flush all information logsmysqladmin -u root -p flush-privileges# Reload the grant tables (same as reload)mysqladmin -u root -p flush-status# Clear status variables kill Sleeping MySQL Client Process12345678mysqladmin -u root -p processlist# to identify sleeping MySQL client processmysqladmin -u root -p kill 5# where 5 is the process IDmysqladmin -u root -p kill 5,10# to kill multiple process (comma separated) run multiple mysqladmin commands together1mysqladmin -u root -p processlist status version Connect remote mysql server (-h for host)1mysqladmin -h 172.16.25.126 -u root -p execute command on remote MySQL server1mysqladmin -h 172.16.25.126 -u root -p status start/stop MySQL replication on a slave server12mysqladmin -u root -p start-slavemysqladmin -u root -p stop-slave store MySQL server Debug Information to logsIt tells the server to write debug information about locks in use, used memory and query usage to the MySQL log file including information about event scheduler. 1mysqladmin -u root -p debug view mysqladmin options and usageTo find out more options and usage of myslqadmin 12mysqladmin --help# display a list of available options Links Installation of MySQL 5.5.28 Server on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora MySQL replication
